svcsection.title: ANTILOCK BRAKES/TRACTION CONTROL: BENDIX - PRINCIPLES, OPERATION AND SERVICE

lev1.title: ANTILOCK BRAKE SYSTEM (ABS)
lev1.para: This service section covers the Antilock Brake System installed as a stand-alone system, ABS with Engine Brake, and ABS with Traction Control system.
During a brake stop, the maximum point of deceleration occurs just before wheel lockup. When wheel lockup occurs, stopping distances increase and loss of directional control may occur.
To reduce wheel lockup, the antilock brake system monitors the rotational speed of the wheels using sensors mounted on the axle ends and exciter rings mounted on the wheel assemblies.

When the wheels rotate, an AC voltage pulse is generated by the sensors that is transmitted to the electronic control unit, which is part of the controller/valve assembly. The controller monitors the pulse rates. During a brake application, if an imbalance is sensed (a wheel is about to lock up), the electronic controller sends a signal to the appropriate modulator valve.

Within a fraction of a second, the modulator valve responds by repeatedly exhausting air from the brake chamber(s), allowing the wheel(s) to speed up, and then automatically applying air (much like a driver pumping the brakes manually).
The antilock system only operates when the controller determines that there is an imbalance (a wheel is about to lock up).
The ABS warning light on the instrument panel illuminates when the controller detects a problem with the system.
The four-channel antilock brake system controls the rear axle brakes (both axles with 6x4) and the front (steering) axle. Wheel sensors are installed on:

item.para: With 4x2 at each rear wheel end.
With 6x4 on one of the two rear axles (one on each wheel end).

lev1.para: The front axle has a modulator valve for each wheel, so that each front wheel/brake assembly is independently controlled by the Controller/Relay Valve. The controller/relay valve is an assembly made up of an Antilock Relay and an Electronic Controller.

The rear axle has a separate modulator valve for the right and left side of the vehicle. With a 6x4, the left modulator valve would control the forward left rear and left rear rear axle brakes, and the right side modulator valve controls the right forward rear and right rear rear brakes. The controller/relay valve controls both front modulator valves and the two modulator valves for the rear axle(s).

lev2.title: REAR AXLE BRAKES WITH 4X2 CHASSIS
lev2.para: The antilock system provides individual wheel control by using a wheel speed sensor and modulator at each wheel to measure rotational speed ( Figure 1). By monitoring the rate of deceleration during braking, and then modifying the service brake application pressure at each wheel, the controller is able to provide improved vehicle braking, while maintaining vehicle stability.

The rear axle brakes are controlled completely independent of each other and brake application pressure at an individual wheel is adjusted solely on the basis of its behavior on the road surface on which it is traveling.

lev2.title: REAR AXLE BRAKES WITH 6X4 CHASSIS
lev2.para: On vehicles equipped with tandem rear axles (6x2 or 6x4), the wheel speed sensors are installed at the wheel ends on the axle most likely to lose traction first. With a 4-spring suspension, the rear axle sensors are located on the Forward Rear axle. On an air suspension, sensors are located on the Rear Rear axle. A single modulator controls both left side rear axle brakes and another modulator controls both right side rear axle brakes. With this arrangement of wheel speed sensors and modulators, both brakes on one side of a tandem rear axle will be modulated as one, since they will most likely be on the same type of road surface.

lev2.title: FRONT (STEERING) AXLE BRAKES
lev2.para: While each steering axle brake is under the control of an individual modulator valve, the controller does not treat these brakes totally independent of each other. The controller utilizes a modified individual control method for steering axle brakes. This is done to minimize "steering wheel pull" in the event that one front wheel is on dry pavement and the other is on a slippery surface, such as ice or snow. The ABS controller controls the braking force differences between the two brakes. The wheel on dry pavement is initially given less braking force and is brought up to optimum during the stop, while the wheel on ice attempts to maintain optimum braking during the entire stop.

lev1.title: ABS WITH AN ENGINE BRAKE
lev1.para: If the ABS controller senses a slippery road condition, it will disengage the engine brake.

lev1.title: TRACTION CONTROL
lev1.para: The traction control system is an extension of the ABS system. The wheel speed sensors not only detect rapid decreases in wheel speed for antilock, but also detect unreasonably high increases for traction control.
Traction control is only available with electronically controlled engines. The differences between an ABS system and an ABS system with traction control are:

item.para: A Traction "Active" light located below the ABS indicator light on the instrument panel in addition to the ABS Warning light.
A Traction Control ON/OFF switch located on the instrument panel.

With traction control and ABS there is a different combination of controller and relay valve. There are programming differences and there is a traction control solenoid (part of the controller/relay valve assembly) that connects to the rear axle wiring with a two-pin connector at the controller/relay valve.

lev1.para: With traction control, a spinning drive wheel is instantly detected and the wheel speed is compared with the other vehicle wheels, both front and rear. The traction control system simultaneously reduces the engine torque setting to a level suitable for the available traction and gently pumps the brake on the spinning wheel. Since the vehicle's differential tends to drive the wheel that has the least resistance (wheel on the slipperiest surface), a slight brake application to this wheel only forces the differential to drive the stationary or slowly spinning wheel.
